quoteFirst: , and sets at 2:21 the next morning; on the 30th, it rises at 1:18 p. m. and sets on the 31st at
quoteLast: It maintains the same diameter, 3.8″, throughout the month, and makes a direct motion of 2° 13′ 45″. On the 23d, at 4:38 a. m., will be 1° 11′ north of the moon.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, May 1885, No. 8
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: The village of Grafton seemed quite near with its three church spires and square-topped town hall tower. They could see the clock on the latter, and Monty, after a surreptitious glance at his watch, said that he could even tell the time, which was
quoteLast: , and Leon believed him at first, and was appropriately surprised by his powers of vision. To the right of the village was the railway station, and they could follow the single line of track for some distance westward.
title: Hitting the line
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Rockwell, Norman, 1894-1978 [Illustrator]
